Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Building Engineering Through Topology Optimization

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the structural engineering of buildings by constructing engineering concepts through topology optimization. Structural topology relates to geometric configurations of components that fit in to the structural system of the building. The goal is to tailor topology optimization techniques to building systems and to use this technology as a means to connect architects and engineers in design of buildings. To achieve this goal, the challenges are to move away from traditional ?box-like? building shapes by exploring innovative bio-inspired and natural artistic designs as well as to enable a formal linkage between structural engineering and architecture.

The proposed techniques for tailored building design will be a novel addition to the realm of topology optimization. This research will explore natural load path topology optimization of tall buildings; will provide integration of structural engineering and architecture design optimization through the final design of buildings; will achieve new advances in lateral bracing systems; and will develop high-fidelity computational models. The computational framework will be formulated to provide both architects and engineers freedom to design innovative buildings that are artistic and yet with pragmatic consideration of economy. The Co-PI, a principal in a consulting engineering company, has background in design of super-tall buildings. The students working in the project will intern in the consulting company and the inter-disciplinary research team will work in close collaboration in all stages of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focuses on tailoring concepts of structural topology optimization to the high-rise building industry by exploring natural systems design and developing efficient computational frameworks to provide both architects and engineers freedom to design innovative structures, while satisfying principles from engineering and mechanics. These frameworks considered a wide spectrum of objectives and practical demands and investigated numerical applications in engineering. Efficient computational frameworks and methodologies were developed in structural topology optimization of continuum and discrete structures with multiple materials, realistic material properties, and subjected to many load cases.

 

Development of efficient frameworks for 2D and 3D ground structure based topology optimization

Structural optimization of truss networks was explored and novel unstructured ground structure methods and computational implementations in 2D and 3D were developed, named GRAND (Ground Structure Analysis and Design) and GRAND3. The ground structure method has been refined, simplified and optimized, resulting in an easy-to-use implementation for truss topology optimization in arbitrary and complex domains. The ground structure based topology optimization integrated uses linear programming (interior point method) to minimize the volume of the structure. GRAND and GRAND3 aim to have a balance between performances and feature user defined connectivity level and restriction zones to prevent the invalid ground structure generation. Noteworthy remark: GRAND and GRAND3 are state-of-the-art educational software which have been made largely available to the engineering community (professionals and students).

 

Development of a procedure for obtaining suitable output for additive manufacturing from topology optimization results

The complexity in results has bounded topology optimization to research and theoretical studies. The emerging additive manufacturing field allows for the realization of complex designs obtained via topology optimization. However, the resulting topologies still require some post-processing before manufacturing. A procedure for obtaining output suitable for additive manufacturing from structures designed using topology optimization was created for both ground structure and density-based methods. Additionally, a visualization tool, TOPslicer was developed in MATLAB to allow for inspection of the design before sending for additive manufacturing. Noteworthy remark: TOPslicer is a state-of-the-art educational software which has been made largely available to the engineering community (professionals and students).

 

Development of filtering strategies for the ground structure method

Ground structure method is a practical engineering tool to optimize truss structures. For the elastic formulation, which typically requires a post-processing cutoff, a novel scheme to filter “real” structures out of ground structures was developed. This filter feature with explicit control on the member areas allows the users to play with alternatives prior to selecting a specific structural configuration. As a result, multiple-choice designs can be obtained, providing flexibility to designers and fostering the relationship between architects and engineers. In addition, an adaptive filtering strategy, maximum filter, was developed that leads to many design perspectives for a single problem and allows for increased user control over the complexity of the final design. To account for practical aspects in real-world designs, a filtering scheme with reduced-order modeling was done for truss topology optimization considering multiple load cases and nonlinear material behaviors.  This scheme accounts for proper load levels, yields the displacement field without artificial stiffness, and reduces the problem sizes within a few iterations, leading to drastically improved computational performance.

 

Development of multi-material topology optimization formulations

Practical engineering designs, such as buildings and aircraft consist of multiple material types. An efficient multi-material topology optimization framework with general volume constraints specifications was developed and applied to ground structures with material nonlinearity. This framework handles an arbitrary number of candidate materials with flexible properties. To handle arbitrary volume constraints efficiently, a novel update scheme, ZPR (Zhang-Paulino-Ramos Jr.) update scheme, has been proposed to perform robust updates of the design variables. As a result, a design tool was developed that not only finds the optimal topology but also selects the proper type and amount of material.

 

Development of efficient randomized methods for topology optimization under many load cases

Practical structural engineering designs typically involve many load cases. The traditional approach minimizes a weighted average of the compliances of all load cases and requires the solution of many large finite element problems in each optimization step, leading to an enormous computational effort. To overcome this issue, a randomized optimization method with stochastic sampling was developed to solve the deterministic optimization problem with many right-hand sides. The developed method significantly improves the computational efficiency by requiring the solution of only a few (e.g., 5 or 6) finite element problems per optimization step while obtaining similar designs to those of standard algorithms. An effective damping scheme for the randomized method was developed based on simulated annealing and leads to rapid convergence of the proposed algorithm.

 

Research findings and knowledge acquired under this award were disseminated through peer-reviewed journal publications, conference presentations and meetings, and many related educational activities and software dissemination (see annual project reports).
